steps.title: Rinse your seeds in lukewarm water.
steps.content: Rinse your seeds in lukewarm water. Discard any split or otherwise obviously damaged seeds. Guarantee the best sprouting results by purchasing seeds specially labeled for sprouting, which are usually tested to guarantee a good germination rate. At the very least, purchase organic seeds. Many non-organic seeds sold for consumption are specially treated not to sprout.

steps.title: Place 1 to 2 tbsp.
steps.content: Place 1 to 2 tbsp. (15-30 mL) of small seeds, or 1/4 to 1/2 cup (60-120 mL) of legumes (beans or lentils) in a quart-size sprouting jar. If you're using a half-gallon jar, use 2 to 4 tbsp. (30-60 mL) of small seeds or 1/2 to 1 cup (120-240 mL) of legumes.

steps.title: Fill the jar with lukewarm water.
steps.content: Fill the jar with lukewarm water. Set the jar upright and leave the seeds to soak. [2] X Research source Optional: Add 1 tsp. (5 mL) of citric acid per quart (950 mL) of soak water. Although this isn't strictly necessary, it will help reduce spoilage. Soak small seeds for 5 or 6 hours. If you're sprouting seeds or beans with a very hard coating, let them soak for as long as 36 hours.

steps.title: Screw a sprouting lid onto the mouth of the jar, if you haven't done so already.
steps.content: Screw a sprouting lid onto the mouth of the jar, if you haven't done so already. Sprouting lids are a hollow ring with a wire- or plastic-mesh insert. When you upend the jar, the water will flow out but the mesh will retain the seeds. [3] X Research source Sprouting lids come in various sizes. For now, select a mesh size that your unsprouted seeds will not fit through.

steps.title: Pour the water out of the sprouting jar.
steps.content: Pour the water out of the sprouting jar. Fill the jar with lukewarm water again, swirl the water and seeds together again, then pour the rinse water out.

steps.title: Prop the jar at an angle, lid facing down.
steps.content: Prop the jar at an angle, lid facing down. This allows any remaining water to drain out of the jar, and air to circulate freely.

steps.title: Continue rinsing the seeds at least twice a day.
steps.content: Continue rinsing the seeds at least twice a day. [4] X Research source Always prop the jar at an angle, lid down, so moisture drains out and air circulates to help prevent spoilage. If you live in an arid climate, rinse the seeds 3 times a day. Mung beans also need more frequent rinsing--3 or 4 times a day--no matter the climate. As the seeds sprout, switch to a larger-mesh sprouting lid for better water and airflow.

steps.title: Place the jar in front of a window once the seeds are fully sprouted.
steps.content: Place the jar in front of a window once the seeds are fully sprouted. This generally takes between 1 and 5 days, depending on the seeds. The sprouts will quickly produce enough chlorophyll to turn green, further enhancing their nutritional value. [5] X Research source The sprouts are ready to eat once the 2 baby leaves are free of the seed hull. Try to eat your sprouts while the root is still one thin thread; once sub-roots begin to appear, the sprouts are much less palatable. [6] X Research source Average sprouting/growth times include: sunflower seeds, 1 to 2 days; clover, 4 days; broccoli, 3 days; alfalfa, 1 to 5 days; mung beans, 3 to 4 days.
